Michael Gillam wrote:

>Hi Colin,
>
>Interesting post!
>  
>
Thanks.

>Just to add a thought to the mix...
>
>One other possibility regarding consciousness is that it is an *emergent*
>property of the network (i.e. not a necessary pursuit and not necessarily
>real.)
>  
>
I think a lot of mystery has been spun around the idea of conciousness 
over the years. It is often (in books, documentaries, etc) discussed as 
some intangible concept that is probably beyond the human mind to 
comprehend. I often recall a sentence in 'Plan and Purpose In Nature' by 
George Williams regarding early work on embyology:
-----------
The "intrinisc processes" of development so impressed the early pioneers 
of experimental biology that many thought it obviously required 
supernatural guidance.
-----------

Although development in biology is still not even close to being fully 
understood, we do understand some of the underlying principles that are 
at work and it's quite inconceivable (to me anyway) to suggest that some 
supernatural forces are at work. And yet this is precisely what some 
have suggested is behind the phenomenon of conciousness. I'm going back 
probably 10 years here but one case of this was Roger Penrose's book 
Shadows Of The Mind in which he attempts to prove mathematically that 
conciousness cannot be described by an algorithm. He then goes on to 
suggest that neuron mitochondria may be somehow describing a much finer 
(than relatively large neurons) information processing network that 
operates at the quantum physical level, perhaps tapping into some 
unknown physical dimension.

Now, while it's an interesting idea it was my interpretation that the 
book was effectively saying that conciousness is something which is 
supernatural and mysterious and it just feels like passing the buck to me.

>We know that almost all known chemical and physicial processes proceed in a
>predetermined direction.  (i.e.  If you were to rewind time and start it
>playing again - the chemical/physical processes would proceed almost
>*exactly* the same.  I say almost - because new quantum theory suggests
>there is a level of inherent unpredictability which might suggest different
>outcomes.)
>  
>
Having recently done some reading on pseudo random number generators it 
makes me wonder if the universe may be using such a generator ;)  And if 
we could perhaps work out the algorithm, hmm :)

>We also know that we can detect thoughts *before* they become conscious.
>(i.e. a portion of neurons in your brain will simulate scratching your nose
>before you consciously decide - "my nose itches" and scratch it.)
>  
>
Sure there is a lot of subconcious activity invoved in things like 
image, sound and sensation processing. A lot of this processing results 
in information that is deemed low value and so we never become aware of 
it. It's like there is a switching and prioritising system controlling 
what we are aware of.

>Taken together, these suggest that consciousness is a *secondary*
>phenomenon, and perhaps an *emergent* property of the network.
>  
>
Yes and no. From an evolutionary point of view it makes sense to have 
all of these sensory inputs to monitor your environment, because even 
without conciousness some simple rules can be applied (instinct) to aid 
survival, e.g. locating food, avoiding hazards. You can then imagine a 
sliding scale of complexity starting at simple systems such as plankton 
that are able to sense their immediate environment and propel themselves 
in a basic manner, right up to something like a crocodile - which AFAIK 
only has a very small brain that is equivalent to our limbic system. 
That's why you can put your head inside a crocs mouth in certain 
circumstances and it won't bite it off - by discovering what a croc's 
instincts are some folks have been able to find gaps in their very 
simple survival strategy such as this.

Now consider that crocs have been around for millions of years without 
hardly changing from an evolutionary point of view. Perhaps they have 
reached the pinacle of what they can achieve without something 
equivalent to the frontal cortex of our brain, which is something which 
evolved after the limibic system but communicates very closely with it. 
This new brain system takes in the same information but is able to 
provide a new level of processing that the limbic system was incapable 
of, like make memories and associations between them.

This more abstract level of processing is what I reckon we would call 
conciousnessness, although I do think that any system that senses it's 
surrounding in some way in order to drive it's behaviour is 'concious' 
to some degree. So I think a croc would percieve me as a pice of 
possible prey, but it wouldn't percieve any fine detail such as, say, 
the colour of my t-shirt :) (if they can even see in colour?). Taken to 
an extreme a plankton is 'concious' of it's immediate surroundings and 
my central heating thermostat is 'concious' of the temp in this room.

It might sound silly but I don't think conciousness is an on/off thing 
that is generated by some specific part of the brain, I think it's a 
consequence of more and more information about our surroundings being 
processed in an ordered manner to drive our behaviour/survival - the 
more deep and abstract the information, the deeper the level of 
conciousness.

Taking the idea a step further, yes it is emergent but you can't just 
put a load of unordered complex systems together  and hope for 
emergence. The interface between the systems has to be ordered, and 
survival of the fittest just happens to have come up with just such an 
ordered system of info processing.

>This observation suggests that a large enough and complex enough network
>could experience this emergent property.  The Internet itself could *think*
>it is sentient - despite the fact that, like us, its thoughts are
>predetermined.  This approach has interesting and dour predictions for
>communication between species.
>  
>
The internet is an intersting case to ponder. Think I'll leave that for 
another day :)

>This approach also suggests that programmers do not have to worry about
>*building* consciousness into a system - it is an *emergent* property of an
>adequately complex adaptive network.
>  
>
Yeh but they need to build the complexity in an ordered and directed 
way. I think the Seed AI people are trying to achieve something like 
this. Actually I don't think they mention conciousness in their goal, 
but I suspect that what they are aiming to build would become concious 
if they ever succeeded.

BTW in case you were wondering, none of these ideas are particularly 
new, it's all just stuff I've read elsewhere.

Colin.
